title: Preparation of Al-Li-Cu-Graphite Composite via High-Energy Ball Milling and Sintering with High-Frequency Induction Heating
content: The powder metallurgy processes have undergone significant advancements with high-energy ball milling (HEBM), facilitating the production of ultra-fine grain alloys and composites exhibiting improved microstructural and mechanical features (Sadeghi et al., 2024). Aluminum matrix composites (AMCs) reinforced with carbon have garnered significant interest because of their low density and impressive mechanical characteristics (Prieto et al., 2008). GraphiteÂ´s (Gr) unique attributes, including a low thermal expansion coefficient and high thermal conductivity, make it an ideal choice for reinforcement (Moghadam et al., 2014). Consequently, aluminum-graphite composites demonstrate enhanced properties such as reduced density, increased strength, and improved toughness. There are many techniques to sinter the obtained powders by HEBM; however, conventional methods promote grain growth due to the high temperature and sintering time, which negatively modifies their mechanical response (Kubota et al., 2010). In recent years, there has been a development and widespread adoption of the high-frequency induction heating technique for sintering nanostructured materials; this approach offers enhanced control over grain growth while the sintering process occurs (Xue et al., 2023).
